awd_titl_txt: Pre-Ignition Biomass Emissions: Causes and Characterization
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is focused on investigating the physical and chemical characteristics of biomass burning emissions in the period before flaming combustion ignites.  Pre-ignition emissions are likely to be responsible for a substantial fraction of the organic aerosol released to the atmosphere from the burning of solid fuels.  The results of this project will be described in two instructional videos to communicate the principles of pre-ignition emissions. This information will be used to inform and educate many in the developing world, that largely rely on solid fuels for cooking and heating, of possible methods for reducing potential exposures to toxic air pollutants from biomass burning.

The objectives of this effort are to: (1) develop a controlled-temperature generator that simulates the physical factors controlling biomass emissions at ignition; (2) develop a "sufficiently empirical" model that predicts emission rates and quantities; (3) confirm factors that control emissions prior to ignition, and identify low- and high-emitting conditions, using capabilities developed during the project; (4) conduct a community comparison experiment to characterize pre-ignition emissions; and (5) develop two low- bandwidth videos to communicate best practices for achieving low emissions.
org_div_long_name: Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated the causes and natures of particles emitted from solid wood (biomass) either before ignition begins, or when a packet of air leaves the burning zone without passing through a flame. These “escaping” emissions make up about 90% of primary organic aerosol released globally. These particles also contribute to adverse respiratory health effects when they are emitted indoors, as they are in many low-income situations.

 Pyrolysis, or the breakdown of wood during heating, precedes combustion in air. We found that principles known in industrial pyrolysis were useful in explaining emission phenomena. Biomass pyrolysis in industry typically uses very small wood particles, and differs quite a bit from the pyrolysis that occurs in most other applications. Wood burned in stoves or forest fires is much larger, and heat has to transfer into the wood before pyrolysis can occur. The breakdown products then have to escape from the wood before they can enter the atmosphere and become aerosol. This transfer of heat-in and mass-out doesn’t happen in industrial pyrolysis. However, when we combined known rates of heat transfer, mass transfer, and wood breakdown in a model, we were able to model experimental rates of release from wood blocks. It was known that heat flux is a dominant factor in rates of breakdown, and we confirmed that principle. We also found that wood density was important.

To understand how biomass emissions might affect atmospheric chemistry, we need to know whether wood breakdown products are emitted as gas, like CO2 and CO, or as particles; we also need to know the chemical composition. We found that the divisions among particles and gases were approximately constant over the whole period of wood decomposition. The released products were similar whether the breakdown was occurring near the surface at the beginning of decomposition, or near the center of the wood at the end, although the products passed through a very hot environment in the latter case. Most measures of chemical composition, such as oxygen-to-carbon ratio, remained constant over the whole period as well. Pyrolysis temperature did affect the composition, and specific wood species produced unique molecules, but the time of emission did not affect the composition. A machine-learning algorithm using measured emission rates confirmed that most of the particle emission rate could be predicted with the modeled mass loss rate, and that including wood density and temperature made the prediction slightly better.

In this work, we also sought to communicate the importance of particle emissions for human health. We produced a short, animated video on indoor air pollution with four major points: Fires make smoke that can harm people, especially children; Keep the smoke away from people; The fuel you use can change the smoke; and Use less fire, breathe less smoke. The video was developed in a way that spoken tracks could be added to communicate in different languages. English, French, Spanish and Chichewa versions are available on the Scientific Animations Without Borders site.

The most important scientific outcome of this work is an update to the way the atmospheric community views emissions from biomass combustion. In the past, emission rates and composition have been described statistically and differences have been ascribed to wood type. This work advances a complementary view of biomass emissions based on physical mechanisms, offering the promise of reducing emissions when conditions can be controlled, and thereby enabling improvements in public health.
